<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">The Races at Longchamp  
1866  
Oil on canvas; 44 × 84.2 cm (17 5/16 × 33 1/8 in.)  
Signed and dated: Manet /1866 (lower right corner, in black paint)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Potter Palmer Collection, 1922.424

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Édouard Manet did not share his friend and rival Edgar Degas’s passion for horses and racecourses. Degas demonstrated this interest over many years, starting in the early 1860s but most actively beginning in the 1870s, producing hundreds of paintings and pastels and innumerable drawings. One drawing made around 1865 even includes a sketch of Manet on a racetrack, looking young and comfortably informal, with a sketchily indicated woman peering through binoculars beside him (fig. 12.1). In contrast to this extensive output, Manet’s racing works consist of just two surviving paintings (one a later, commissioned work; fig. 12.2; [RW I 184]); a couple of oil sketches (RW I 97; RW I 98); fragments cut from a large canvas now otherwise lost (RW I 94; RW I 95); a gouache and watercolor study (RW II 548); a graphite and watercolor drawing (RW II 544); a lithograph (Harris 41); and a handful of graphite notebook sketches; all were part of a single project (see below for illustrations). Yet it was Manet who first attempted a racetrack scene, initially on a monumental scale; he spent a considerable amount of time and creative energy trying to complete it before settling for a much smaller version—the Art Institute’s canvas—perhaps a decade after he began.

This relatively small picture brings viewers face to face with a dramatic, head-on rush of jockeys and horses galloping as if exploding from a distant mass of trees in the background, and urged on by serried ranks of excited spectators, standing behind the barrier to the left of the rails, or watching the race from horse-drawn carriages. A pink banner, flapping from a pole in the distance above a flurry of parasols, links the colorful caps and silks of the jockeys to the animated crowd on the other side of the track. There, figures recede into the distance from below the roof of a covered stand: a simple, rectangular shape that juts into the picture from the right, emphasizing the flatness of the canvas yet also the sense of speed, recession, and limitless space. A sweep of green hills high up on the canvas, on the distant horizon, is “pinned” to the foreground and the picture plane by the circular top of a furlong marker on the track. Urban buildings rising above the trees to the right are underpinned by that same sharply defined roof projection, which brings distance and foreground together and focuses the viewer’s eye on the central drama of the race.

Looking at this wonderfully compact, dynamic painting, it is impossible to believe that it was once over three times larger, and that the artist reduced it to its current size. But, as conservation examination has revealed, the painting has been cropped on the left, top, and bottom sides and the original painting has been folded over to serve as the new tacking margins on those sides. On the right edge, the original tacking margin is largely intact; the paint extends just beyond the current foldover, and there is a narrow band of unpainted primed canvas (fig. 12.3). This earlier stage of painting is most clearly visible where the grassy track extends below the final composition’s bottom edge.

When all Manet’s surviving works for this ambitious project are brought together, it is possible to begin reconstructing the process by which he created the Chicago painting. These works include: quick graphite sketches made in a notebook at an unidentified racecourse (now in various collections; see fig. 12.4); an oil sketch on canvas of horses and jockeys in an arrangement very similar to that in the final painting (RW I 96), hitherto known only from a photograph taken by Fernand Lochard (fig. 12.5); an almost identical watercolored drawing (fig. 12.6; [RW II 544]); an impressive panoramic watercolor with gouache that shows the scene extending far to the left of the final composition (as it does in the notebook drawings [fig. 12.4]) but was cropped top and bottom as part of Manet’s progressive attempts to reduce what was likely a wide, empty foreground in the initial versions of the painting (fig. 12.7; [RW II 548]), as recorded in the (reversed) image of a lithograph (fig. 12.8; cat. 13; [Harris 41]); and, finally, two fragments cut by Manet from an earlier and even larger canvas than the original version of the Chicago picture (fig. 12.9; [RW I 94] and fig. 12.10; [RW I 95]). One of the latter (fig. 12.9)—currently unlocated and known only from a black-and-white reproduction—relates to figures seen, thanks to technical imaging, beneath the present surface of the Chicago picture, in the lower left corner of the final, cut canvas (fig. 12.11).

There are also many documentary clues: lists and exhibition catalogues with varying titles and the names of various racecourses; annotations on the posthumous documentation of the artist’s studio and references in his correspondence, which sometimes help clarify the issue but also sometimes further confuse it; and dates inscribed by the artist on some of the related works. Scholars have read this information in various ways in the past. But recent developments in both documentary and scientific investigation, as well as increased collaboration among institutions, now make possible a more comprehensive understanding of the related works and their context.

Manet worked on many projects simultaneously, ever aware of deadlines for exhibitions and submissions to the official Salon jury. Yet this remarkable productivity was accompanied by a rich and varied social life, complicated family relationships, and relationships with a circle of artist colleagues and close friends that included critics, composers, musicians, novelists, poets, politicians, and publishers—all of which in some way fed into his art. Manet’s health also affected his work, and it may have been one of many factors in the evolution of this horse-racing project. Since this was one of the most complex of all his projects in the 1860s and was not concluded until the beginning of the following decade, understanding how the work reached its final form will shed light on the artist’s creative activity more generally. The present attempt to grasp the development and scope of Manet’s ambitious project draws on earlier investigations and is the first to assemble all of the information presently available, but it will certainly not be the last.

The most recent in-depth investigation of Manet’s project has confirmed that his earliest known exhibition of a horse-race painting was in February 1864, when a work titled Les Courses de Chantilly was listed as no. 165 in an exhibition catalogue of the Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts, at 26, boulevard des Italiens in Paris. Manet had shown several works in changing displays at Louis Martinet’s gallery in 1861, and he famously presented a small “solo show” of a dozen or more works within a larger exhibition of many artists held there from March 1, 1863, shortly before the sending-in dates for the opening of the Salon in May. One of Manet’s most controversial works in Martinet’s show was listed (but not illustrated) among a group of anonymous caricature drawings. Numbered 135, and labeled Le jardin des Tuileries (see fig. 12.12), the ironic text that accompanied the illustrations announced that the painting had been sold to the department store La Belle Jardinière, and that the author had arrived too late to see it.

Music in the Tuileries (fig. 12.12; RW I 51), in which Manet portrayed himself, members of his family, and friends and colleagues from his social and professional circles, is signed and dated 1862, while preparatory graphite sketches for the many figures who appear in it were made in a notebook on pages with an 1855 watermark. His sketches of the crowd at a racetrack also came from this notebook—the earliest evidence that Manet visited such a site (fig. 12.13; [RW II 176]). From the same notebook comes a sketch of a figure on a beach, looking toward the sea and a ship (fig. 12.14; [RW II 268]), which Manet would almost certainly have drawn at Boulogne-sur-Mer, where he spent childhood holidays, where he first exhibited a painting (in the local art society’s annual exhibition, in the summer of 1860), and where a well-established racecourse existed not far from the town.

We still have little understanding of what prompted Manet to undertake paintings of horse racing. Did a social visit to a racetrack spark his interest? Or did Manet make an initial decision that racing might be an appropriate subject for a contemporary artist and then take steps to find the material for such a painting? Horse racing was an essentially English sport that became immensely popular in the early years of the nineteenth century. Exciting and entertaining, it also accorded with the British passion for gambling. Wealthy owners commissioned painted portraits of their champion horses and jockeys, and of famous races, and a huge market developed for their reproduction as colored aquatints. Countless examples were published to celebrate racing prizes such as the Epsom Derby, as well as more local, provincial events, with full details supplied in the engraved texts. In France, racing flourished at Chantilly from 1834, and Napoleon III actively promoted it during the Second Empire, during which (in 1857) the famous Longchamp racecourse was inaugurated in the Bois de Boulogne in Paris. By mid-century, Manet would have been well aware of English sporting prints, as these were widely available, including at Adolphe Goupil’s gallery in Paris, and were used by many artists, from Degas to Théodore Géricault. We can find evidence of Manet’s awareness in one of his very rare surviving notebooks, one with its binding intact and its pages watermarked with the date 1856 (the year he left Thomas Couture’s studio), and an assortment of annotations at each end. One side contains references to piano pieces by Johann Sebastian Bach, Franz Liszt, and Robert Schumann; a reference to a “boxing scene”; and the name and address of a “very beautiful, tall brunette” (presumably a model). The other end (turned around as another “front”) bears a list of subjects: “woman arranging flowers,” “man and woman giving [?] to a little girl,” “a racing event,” “Paris street on the boulevard Montmartre,” and “boxing scene, England.” The music would have been of interest to Suzanne Leenhoff (the artist’s companion, model, and, eventually, wife), who was an accomplished pianist, and the contact information of the model relevant for studio studies. In the list of subjects, the reference to “England” suggests English sporting prints, whose subjects included boxing matches as well as horses, hunting, and related activities (as mentioned above).

Manet’s racetrack sketches are both revealing and frustrating, since the exact locations of their subjects have not yet been identified. They do not show the track itself, or the horses and jockeys seen in the painting, but concentrate instead on glimpses of the crowd standing by the barrier that borders the track, or of the scene behind a second barrier that marked off the pedestrian area: coachmen and the carriages in which serious racegoers could stand for a better view and fashionable ladies could see the race in comfort and be seen (fig. 12.15; [RW II 546]). A few sketches show the view farther to the left (fig. 12.16; [RW II 494 verso], fig. 12.17; [RW II 547 verso], fig. 12.18; [RW II 547 recto]). One connects a coachman on a foreground carriage with this more distant area, closed off on the left by a marquee topped with a flag (fig. 12.17; [RW II 547] verso). The setting appears entirely rural and is dominated by a mighty hill that rises steeply behind the marquee, with its crest extending to the right, far above and behind the crowd massed along the track. What may be a distant banner marking the starting point of the race flies at the center of two sketches, drawn on both sides of a page oriented horizontally (fig. 12.19; [RW II 545 recto], fig. 12.18; [RW II 545 verso]). One of the sketches includes the furlong marker with its circular top that is such a striking feature in the painting (fig. 12.19; [RW II 545 recto]). These are swift notations, jotted down by Manet as he twisted and turned to catch general views and ever-changing aspects of the crowd. The graphite line skitters lightly, sometimes barely legibly, over the pages, but these shorthand ciphers sufficed for the artist to reconstruct the scene in various guises.

The absence of any architectural structures in the background and the fact that the artist must have been standing on the track itself, in the path of horses galloping toward the finish, suggest that these views may have been sketched at an informal country racecourse, very possibly on the cliff tops to the north of Boulogne. Racing had been established at Hobengue (now Aubengue) since the 1830s, and in 1855 Emperor Napoleon III ordered troops in the army encampments on the cliffs to open up a road from Boulogne, which made access much easier for crowds from the fashionable harbor town. The courses and venues changed over time, with a steeplechase added to the flat racing course, but elegant holidaymakers from Boulogne and punters from Paris, as well as pickpockets from as far afield as London, flocked to the races between Wimille and Ambleteuse, high on the cliffs overlooking the Straits of Dover.

The significance of Manet’s slight graphite notations, to which he must have returned as memory aids, emerges when their sequence (fig. 12.4) is compared to an impressive composition, in watercolor, gouache, and black ink, which he must have made in preparation for the Chicago painting in its initial, much larger form (fig. 12.7). Although this work on paper corresponds with a later stage in Manet’s project and was cut down by the artist at top and bottom, it provides a clear idea of the panoramic sweep of his initial concept for a Salon-scale picture. The sketches helped to create a “painterly” composition, providing a reference for the crucial additions of the horses and jockeys, and the barrier and crowd to the right of the track.

The notebook sketches remain the only proof that Manet actually visited a racecourse. But when and how did he combine those views with the group of horses and jockeys? One of the works listed and photographed in Manet’s studio after his death in 1883 was a small oil sketch of a group of five horses and jockeys (see fig. 12.5). It appears as no. 32 in the register of works compiled by Léon Leenhoff (Suzanne’s son), who looked after the practical arrangements for the artist’s estate and arranged for photographs to be taken to illustrate the works listed in his register (fig. 12.20). In the register, Leenhoff’s initial description of “petite courses esq[uisse]” (small races sketch) was scored through and replaced by “Etude de Courses” (Study for Races), followed by notes that it was “encadré Nivard”—that is, framed by one of Manet’s habitual suppliers, Nivard—and had been photographed. Below, Leenhoff recorded the work’s dimensions in centimeters: “32 / 41” (fig. 12.21). A group of unmounted contact prints in the Prints and Photographs department of the Bibliothèque Nationale de France includes a very rare untrimmed example of the photograph which shows the whole canvas, placed upright on its right side on an easel for the photographer (fig. 12.22).

This oil sketch, bought by Gustave Caillebotte at the estate sale in February 1884, remained virtually unrecorded from that time until the 1950s. It remains unlocated, although the search continues. We find no exact correlation of formats, outlines, or shapes with similar works, including those with just five horses and riders—the apparently traced drawing, lightly touched with watercolor (fig. 12.6; [RW II 544 ), and the painting on a very small wood panel (fig. 12.23; [RW I 97])—and those with six figures. This suggests that further original or intermediate works are missing, unless the artist transferred his designs freehand from one support to another. Nevertheless, the “traced” appearance of the watercolored drawing suggests that Manet may have used an English sporting print as a model for this striking and unusual image of the head-on, frontal gallop. The great majority of such prints show the horses in profile, in the traditional “flying gallop” pose, with their hooves off the ground and all four legs fully extended (fig. 12.24). However, illustrations of country steeplechases, and even of the Epsom Derby, had displayed the head-on rush of horses and jockeys at the start of a race, and this may well have provided Manet with motifs that he could use in his painting, if not an exact model. One such print is a record of the Leamington Grand Steeple Chase of 1837, while another shows the beginning of the Derby (fig. 12.25). It is unclear why Manet chose this unusual view when the “flying gallop” was considered so effective for suggesting the speed and excitement of race horses. Even after Eadweard Muybridge’s stop-motion photographic studies had demonstrated, in 1878, that it was anatomically incorrect—not to mention physiologically impossible—artists continued to use the old formula, of which the most famous example in France (which Manet may have well seen) is the canvas painted by Théodore Géricault in England in 1821, sold in Paris in 1866 as The Derby of 1821 at Epsom, and acquired by Emperor Napoleon III for the Musée du Louvre (fig. 12.26).

Manet’s early, large-scale works may help account for his choice of an unorthodox view. He pursued many major projects at once in his studio. For those he began on the premises he occupied immediately upon leaving Couture’s studio school in 1856, he drew inspiration from his intense study of Old Master paintings, particularly of the Venetian school. He saw and copied these in the magnificent collection in the Louvre and on visits to Italy in 1853 and 1857, and he also studied them through large and detailed engraved reproductions available first at the Bibliothèque Nationale and then at the Imperial Library.

While it remains uncertain when in the 1860s Manet began his horse-racing project, it was probably while he was still at work on Le déjeuner sur l’herbe (Luncheon on the Grass; fig. 12.27; [RW I 67]), which he signed and dated in 1863 after extensively transforming the composition. It was originally much closer to its Italian Renaissance source in the work of Titian, but Manet altered it over several years to achieve the “modern” mode he was aiming for. The results profoundly shocked the public in 1863, when he showed Déjeuner at the Salon des Refusés. More to the present point, it was while working on this painting that Manet likely arrived at the compositional strategy he used in Races.

During his time with Couture, while Manet was immersed in study of the Old Masters, he was already obsessed with creating contemporary subjects based on their example. His initial compositional idea for Déjeuner (presented at the Salon des Refusés in 1863 as Le Bain [Bathing]), as well as his oil sketch for a large-scale Moses Saved canvas (fig. 12.28; [RW I 39]) both owe a debt to one of Titian’s grandest paintings in the Louvre, then called Jupiter and Antiope but later known as Pardo Venus (fig. 12.29). Manet copied it in a lively oil study. Both the oil sketch and, above all, the initial, underlying design of Déjeuner sur l’herbe (visible in an X-radiograph; fig. 12.30) show how attentive Manet was to Titian’s composition. A group of foreground figures appear against a grassy area backed by slim trees, while the larger area opens up a deep perspective view of distant mountains, through a hunting scene in the middle distance, with a stag at bay, twisting and turning on splayed legs to escape the hounds, while a huntsman and more dogs advance from the right. Manet’s copy after Titian’s Pardo Venus may have been made specifically as preparation for the works he began after he left Couture’s studio early in 1856, and Titian is reflected rather than imitated in his horse-racing scene. As the artist worked his way through his early “translations” of Titian’s painting, he would have realized that it was possible to move directly from the concept and format of its composition to an entirely modern subject, loosely based on a similar arrangement of smaller and larger parts—the larger area concerned with perspectival recession—and that this could be achieved without revealing the Old Master connections apparent in his earlier paintings, and which he later obscured through his radical reworking of the Déjeuner to suppress the distant landscape.

To the crowd at the racecourse in his notebook sketches, and the space that extends behind it to the left, Manet added the horses and jockeys galloping furiously up the track to the right, opening up the equivalent of Titian’s vista into deep space. Exploring the comparison further, his crowd by the racetrack is equivalent to the female bathers on the river bank at the very center of Titian’s painting. Their compositional alignment with the stag hunt in the middle ground and a huntsman and hounds who thrust forward from the right edge of the painting is paralleled by Manet’s agitated crowd on the other side of the track, and the jutting roof of the stand, which similarly connects the middle distance with the picture plane and the surface of the canvas while also emphasizing the sense of recession and of rapid movement. However, the balance of action and atmosphere in Titian’s and Manet’s works differ. In the majestic panorama of Titian’s painting, Cupid with his bow and arrow arches overhead, connecting the two parts of the design with a sweeping movement that embraces the entire composition, while figures and a large, upright plant fill the foreground below and extend across the full width of the canvas. By contrast, in Manet’s original, large-scale composition (fig. 12.27), the artist appears to have left the foreground entirely empty—a striking feature of some of the English sporting prints already cited (fig. 12.24), in which “vanishing lines” emphasize the expanse of grass ahead of the galloping horses and jockeys who splay out to secure advantageous positions for the race. At any event, Manet’s decision, perhaps made from the start, to combine (from notebook sketches) a panoramic view of limited depth on the left with (from the large watercolor drawing; fig. 12.7) a plunge into deep space beyond the barrier that held back the crowd, left him with an unbalanced composition that had no clear, single viewpoint (or even clear multiple viewpoints) that could be harmonized and unified, as in Titian’s painting.

In the late 1850s and early 1860s, at the start of his artistic career, Manet worked in a variety of modes and genres, from the single figure of a social misfit in his Absinthe Drinker (fig. 12.31; [RW I 19]) through a penetrating double portrait of his parents (fig. 12.32; [RW I 30]), to the elegant crowd of his friends and family in the Tuileries in 1862 (fig. 12.12; [RW I 58]). In the same year he also depicted a festive and socially mixed crowd watching one of the most popular entertainments of the day, the ascent of a balloon, in a lithograph signed and dated 1862, and intended for publication (fig. 12.33; [Harris 23]). As Manet’s first attempt at a truly original lithograph, this print provides a very interesting counterpart to his even bolder, not to say wildly handled, image of the racetrack (fig. 12.8). On one hand, the work can be read as politically motivated: the compact composition centers on the balloon, symbol of human progress and freedom, which effectively blocks out the view of the distant Invalides, which at the time signified the results of imperial power politics and its military consequences. On the other hand, the print can be seen to depict a dynamic celebration of a popular entertainment that expressed modern concepts of speed and gain, time and money. Manet creates an astonishing plunge into space, with an off-center vanishing point that pulls the viewer into the image. He reduces bystanders at the barrier to scribbled marks, a few coachmen are recognizable, and the ladies in carriages are very roughly indicated.

In the Balloon lithograph, onlookers on the left—in particular a handsome, veiled woman seen in profile—recall the “portraits” in his Tuileries picture. In that work, the two ladies sitting together likely held no particular significance for viewers, who saw in the work nothing but meaningless “dabs” of color when it was exhibited in Martinet’s gallery the following year, but every individual depicted held meaning for the artist. It seems highly likely that personal connections helped shape Manet’s racecourse scene in its earliest known form—such play was crucial to Manet’s approach to both art and life—especially the carefully delineated spectators who are closest to the viewer (fig. 12.10). Manet’s panoramic watercolor drawing, made to clarify his composition after its initial stage, then cut down at top and bottom and cut in two, then reconnected, provides more information than can yet be fully analyzed. It must reflect alterations Manet had already made to his original large canvas, an otherwise unknown work listed (as mentioned above) as no. “165. Manet.—Les Courses de Chantilly” in the catalogue of the first exhibition of the National Society of Fine Arts, held in February 1864 in Martinet’s galleries on the boulevard des Italiens. This would be the work from which Manet later cut two fragments, signed and dated 1866, that show figures from his foreground group (fig. 12.9 and fig. 12.10).

For the society’s next exhibition, which was due to open on February 19, 1865, Manet wrote to Martinet with a list of nine works that he intended to show, including a view of a race, this time in the Bois de Boulogne—“aspect d’une course au bois de Boulogne”—at the immensely popular Longchamp course, inaugurated in 1857. He is recorded as having sent six paintings, all of which he withdrew when only two had been hung for the opening, and there is nothing at present to indicate which paintings were briefly seen in Martinet’s gallery. Although in a letter to Baudelaire Manet referred to the nine canvases as “inédites” (“unpublished”—in other words, entirely new), his racecourse in the Bois de Boulogne could have been a considerably altered version of his “Chantilly” picture of the previous year.

In one of the two fragments cut from the 1865 canvas, signed and dated by Manet the following year (fig. 12.10; the other remains unlocated), technical examination has revealed extensive alterations. The nearer woman in a gray coat and dress was repositioned or added over a previously modified area of the composition. It is clear to the naked eye that she was broadly brushed, in part over existing green grass that is visible behind and through the lower part of her skirt, particularly where the grass extends to the right beyond the wooden post. This bright green was in turn overpainted with a unified, blue-green pigment on which Manet added his signature and the date. The earlier green grass is also visible through the hem of the woman in yellow, who is less affected than her companion by underlying (and as yet unreadable) alterations around her shoulders. Areas of strong wiping or scraping back to the white preparation on the canvas also suggest extensive reworking of the composition, such as in the area at the right edge of the cut fragment, where a young boy in a cap, with his arm supported by one of the boundary ropes, was broadly brushed over the remains of brown pigment through which the white preparation shows in turn.

Manet must have decided to eliminate the woman in yellow and the child before rethinking his composition in the panoramic watercolor (fig. 12.7). There they are replaced by a man in a top hat standing between the woman in gray and a woman in white who holds a parasol in front of her, and a rear view of a third woman just beyond, her head obscured by a large parasol. Both of these two women (the one in white and the one in yellow), represented in the earlier, unlocated canvas fragment, reappear, tellingly, in the underlying design of Manet’s final version of the painting, as revealed by X-radiography, although only as much of them as survived in the lower left corner after the final reduction of the Chicago canvas (fig. 12.11).

So who were all these figures in the earlier and later versions of his painting? How do they fit into the evolving composition, and can they be identified? They were grouped as recognizable spectators at the front and near the center of the original, panoramic composition, where the solid wooden barrier gives way first to spaced posts and then to taller, more rustic poles, widely spaced and joined by rope or wire (as in Manet’s aforementioned notebook sketches; see fig. 12.18; [RW II 547 recto]; and fig. 12.34; [RW II 545 verso]), and where their costumes were almost fully visible (as in the cut canvas fragments and the cropped watercolor). All look in the direction of the galloping horses and jockeys except the nearest woman in gray. In the Cincinnati canvas, she stands quietly, her gaze unfocused, her face almost fully frontal and encircled by a black foulard. She appears as a soft, expansive figure, brushed, as already seen, over a reworked section of Manet’s 1864 and/or 1865 pictures intended for or actually exhibited at Martinet’s galleries, and as she would have appeared, for the last time, in the still only somewhat reduced format of his final version, as exhibited in his major solo show on the place de l’Alma in 1867. It may not be too fanciful to relate the young woman’s pale, round face, circled in black and placed atop a repositioned wooden pole in the watercolor, with the furlong marker so prominently depicted above the crowd, as if this figure was “marked” by the artist in some special way, not as a winning post, but with some suggestion of a prize.

Manet is thought to have exhibited a beautiful early portrait of Suzanne in an art society exhibition in Bordeaux in 1866 (fig. 12.35; [RW I 136]). That Suzanne may have been part of Manet’s racecourse project from the start, given her presence in that work and so many other of his early works, is supported by the fact that she is almost certainly identifiable as the much later and clearly older woman in beige (her strong pianist’s hands always featured by Manet), in a reshaping of the rearview, right-hand woman in the Cognacq fragment for the final version of the Chicago painting. In the Chicago painting, her back is turned to the hastily added figure of the artist’s celebrated model Victorine, recently returned to Paris. She was a last-minute addition, in 1872, that obscured the woman on the left in the Cognacq fragment, in the final version of Manet’s Races at Longchamp. And, returning to the Cincinnati fragments (dated 1866), if the young woman in gray is indeed Suzanne, the nearby woman in yellow was likely related to her—her sister Martina?—while the child, so roughly cut at the edge of the canvas, would make sense as young Léon, already a model for many of Manet’s paintings, and identifiable as the little boy in Music in the Tuileries. In other words, the artist’s “family” would have been present in the picture possibly before his marriage in 1863, with the faithful and beloved Suzanne still a presence when he completed his great project a decade later.

In spite of all that remains unknown and much lost material evidence, comparison of the panoramic watercolor with Manet’s final, drastically reduced and restructured canvas reveals an amazing journey: from the reality of notes taken on a racecourse and an image probably copied from an English sporting print, via study and copies after Titian and an attributed Diego Rodriguez de Velázquez (and a later revelation in the Prado), to experimentation with large-scale, diffusely descriptive works, resulting in a masterpiece, an astonishing “impression” of speed conveyed through a tautly geometrical structure that sends dynamic forces surging across the picture plane and throughout the composition. Every element retained from earlier, panoramic views—directional line, the patterning of tone and color—has been stringently restructured into a network of alignments and forces that generate energy and directly affect the viewer’s response. One of the most visually significant alignments is that of the man with binoculars, perhaps adopted from William Powell Frith’s Derby Day (fig. 12.36) and present in Manet’s earlier, similarly rambling and descriptive watercolor. In Manet’s painting (fig. 12.37), the man’s raised arms are pinpointed by a projection of the base of the barrier on the right, and even by the placement of Suzanne’s hands and the projection of her parasol. Another important visual alignment is the locking, already described, of the furlong marker and the distant hill, which unites the background and foreground grassy track.

A final, prodigious burst of creative activity enabled Manet to involve the viewer in a thrilling physical and emotional experience, in the guise of a fun day out at the races. Following the debacle at the Salon of 1865 over Olympia (RW I 58) and Jesus Mocked (cat. 5; RW I 74), which he had slowly “modernized” away from their Old Master origins, Manet made an urgent visit to Madrid to study “Maestro Velázquez.” Studying the Spanish artist’s work finally freed Manet, desperate but defiant, to pursue his own path and his own original aims. As he told a young colleague: “Concision in art is a necessity and a matter of elegance. . . . Always aim for concision . . . You must always lead the dance and provide entertainment. Don’t make it a chore, no, never a chore.” Discreetly hiding the infinite pains he took, and his total commitment to his art, Manet invited every viewer of his work to enjoy, to participate, and to understand that, as he said in another context, “everything that has a sense of humanity, a sense of modernity, is interesting; everything that lacks these is worthless.” Manet’s Races at Longchamp is perhaps the first truly “modern” artistic project to have emerged, hand in hand with the great art of the past, from post-Revolutionary upheavals, from Romanticism and Realism, into what the artist hoped would become an ever more liberal, democratic, and humane society. In the final analysis, his contribution to that goal is coextensive with the relevance and quality of his oeuvre, within which this painting ranks as an ultimate masterpiece.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Édouard Manet’s The Races at Longchamp is a fragment of a larger composition. Manet cut the canvas and folded over part of the composition onto the top, bottom, and left tacking edges. The composition was not cropped on the right edge; it ends just past the right foldover and a narrow band of unpainted ground at the edge of the canvas indicates that this corresponds to the original edge of the larger painting. The current stretcher, which may be original, is not a standard size. The canvas weave is very fine and exhibits a warp-thread match with Manet’s Jesus Mocked by the Soldiers (cat. 5), which suggests that the canvases for these paintings originated from the same bolt of fabric. The off-white ground consists of a single layer. The initial paint layers, which often remain visible through the open brushwork, were extensively scraped down by the artist. Areas of the sky and landscape were broadly painted with some blending of the brushwork and localized areas of wet-on-wet paint application. Manet built up the crowds of spectators on either side of the racetrack using daubs and dashes of paint, only articulating details and facial features in a few areas, including some figures near the left edge. After the new dimensions of the composition were established, Manet continued to develop the painting and made a few changes. The dress and hat of the female figure in the lower left corner were repainted in a different style, the horizon at the left edge was significantly altered, and the legs of some of the horses were moved.

The multilayer interactive image viewer is designed to facilitate the viewer’s exploration and comparison of the technical images (fig. 12.38).

The ground extends to all edges of the canvas but the canvas has been cut down on the top, bottom, and left edges. The ground has a brushmarked texture that continues onto the right tacking edge (fig. 12.43). Some sweeping lines visible in the X-ray appear to originate from the ground and suggest the use of a palette knife in its application (fig. 12.44). The earliest paint layers applied to the canvas were scraped down in broad areas of the composition, in some places right down to the canvas. The scraped underlayers remain visible throughout areas of the foliage (fig. 12.47), the racetrack (fig. 12.48), and the crowds on the left and right sides (fig. 12.49), and seem to constitute a very broad lay-in or toning of the main areas of the composition. Over the scraped paint layers, the composition was then built up using thicker brushstrokes, often worked wet-in-wet. In some places, the scraped underlayer plays a role in the final forms; for example, in the parasol held by the female figure in the left foreground, the scraped dark-gray underlayer provides some of the general midtone for the parasol, remaining visible in between and around the more impasted touches and linear strokes that define the planes and details of the form (fig. 12.50, fig. 12.51). The sky was built up using very thin initial layers that allow the ground to show through, overlaid by thicker strokes, worked wet-in-wet to delineate the clouds and the intense blue patches of the sky (fig. 12.52).

The background landscape is composed of a more continuous buildup of paint with some blending of the brushstrokes (fig. 12.53). On the left side, a purplish-gray underlayer is visible in areas of open brushwork (fig. 12.54), while some ocher-colored tones show through the upper paint layers on the right side of the landscape (fig. 12.55). The trees along the right horizon were first painted using a dark green similar to the paint visible at the right edge of the canvas; this was scraped down and a thin layer of greenish-gray paint was applied on top, creating a sense of atmospheric perspective in that area. The deeper-toned underlayers are visible in places where the peaks of the brush ridges are exposed (fig. 12.56). The dark-green trees in the right middle distance appear to have been worked up when the background landscape and sky were already dry. Some of the yellowish-green strokes between and below the trees were then applied, overlapping the dark-green paint at the edges (fig. 12.57). The spectators on the left and right sides of the track consist largely of overlapping dashes and touches of paint that contain little specific detail but occasionally suggest top hats, dark clothing, and colorful dresses and parasols (fig. 12.58, fig. 12.59). The brushwork appears to have been rapidly executed with a considerable degree of wet-on-wet application. Only a few figures close to the left edge received more detailed treatment. These include the two females at the lower left corner, the two women riding in the carriage, and the man in the top hat looking through binoculars; however, on closer examination, even these figures are very sketchily rendered (fig. 12.60, fig. 12.61, fig. 12.62). The horses and jockeys were constructed with thick strokes applied mainly wet-on-wet (fig. 12.63, fig. 12.64, fig. 12.65, fig. 12.66). In some places, the jockeys were painted atop or overlapping the trees behind; in other areas, some final green strokes were added last, coming down around the edges of the figures. Some final strokes from the track and the dust clouds come up over the edges of the horses, partially obscuring their legs (fig. 12.67).

The canvas was cut down on the top, bottom, and left sides; the composition was subsequently folded over onto the tacking edges, continuing to the cut edges of the canvas on those sides. On the right side, the composition ends just beyond the current foldover, with a narrow band of unpainted ground at the extreme right edge of the canvas, indicating that the right edge corresponds to the original edge of the larger canvas (fig. 12.41). The painting was cropped after the composition was well established but before it was built up to its final state. Along the bottom edge, the racetrack, the fence, and the dresses of the two female figures continue onto the folded-over part of the canvas. On the left edge, one can see the continuation of the sky, the landscape, and the crowd, including the head and shoulder of a male figure donning a top hat. The top tacking edge is more deteriorated and dirty than the others but the gray paint of the sky continues to the edge of the canvas in a few places. All three edges seem to represent an earlier painting stage compared with adjacent areas on the current picture plane, where Manet continued to develop the image.

Once the new dimensions were established the artist continued to build up the painting and make changes to the composition, especially along the left edge. The dress of the female figure in the lower left corner was originally painted in a very light bluish-gray. The initial painting of the dress remains visible on the left and bottom tacking edges and through the thin blue paint that was applied on top (fig. 12.68, fig. 12.69), and suggests that the figure’s back and shoulder were slightly broader. At the bottom edge, blue paint from the final dress comes down over the pale bluish-gray of the earlier dress; some of this deeper-blue paint appears to have been wiped away from the edge in a fairly straight horizontal line that may indicate the use of some kind of guide (fig. 12.70). Features of the earlier dress, often rendered with light graphic strokes of black paint, remain visible through the upper layer of blue. It appears that some of the dark painted lines were partially wiped or scraped away, with residual paint left in the recesses of the underlying brushstrokes (fig. 12.71). Details of the first dress are somewhat enhanced in the infrared and X-ray images, which appear to show a high-waisted sash, a collar with a black tie at the neck, a double-stranded necklace, a different hat brim, an open parasol held in front of the woman’s skirt, and possibly a shawl draped over the proper right arm (fig. 12.72). In all of these areas the earlier paint layers were dry when the blue dress and the new hat were painted on top. The repainting of the dress appears to have been very quick and cursory. The thin blue paint is rather uniformly applied with little indication of form. A few details, including the white piping and buttons, were added last. Some of the dark lines on the right side of the figure were also added later. The figure’s left arm, bent up toward her face, was also added in the reworking. The repainting of the hat includes the strokes of black and gray paint, as well as the touches of green, red, and off-white applied at the top (fig. 12.73). Further up the left edge, the horizon was lowered by approximately 3 cm and the two rounded tree forms, which were originally larger and closer to the edge, were painted out with the light-gray paint that extends the sky. The two trees were then repainted slightly smaller and further to the right. The earlier horizon is visible in the infrared image (fig. 12.74), and the previous green paint can be seen through the pale-gray layer of the reworked sky near the left edge and remains exposed on the left tacking edge where the composition was not reworked (fig. 12.75).

Manet also made adjustments to the positions of some of the horses’ legs, which can be seen in the infrared image (fig. 12.76). Traces of dark paint from the prior painting are exposed at the surface in places (fig. 12.77), and ridges from the underlying brushstrokes are visible in raking light in some areas (fig. 12.78). The infrared image also shows a couple of curved lines in the area of the bushes underneath the pink banner, suggesting that the bushes may have been laid in differently and in a lower position (fig. 12.79). Traces of dark-brown paint underneath the landscape between the carriage driver at the extreme left edge and the man with binoculars seem to suggest that there may have been some additional figures included in the crowd at an earlier stage (fig. 12.80).

There is some evidence that Manet inscribed a border or defined the edge of the composition by using a rigid tool to scrape into the soft paint on the right edge, which is also the original edge of the larger composition. The scraped line seems to be confined to a narrow band at the edge of the painting that was not reworked, suggesting that the treatment relates to the larger composition before it was cropped. The line veers from the picture plane over the foldover onto the tacking edge, suggesting that it may have been scraped with the canvas flat, before it was stretched. Areas of exposed ground and canvas appear along the trough created (fig. 12.81; fig. 12.82).

Brushes, including approximately 0.5 and 1.0 cm width, flat ferrule (based on width and shape of brushstrokes).

Analysis indicates the presence of the following pigments: lead white, zinc white, zinc yellow, chrome yellow, iron-containing and umber-based earth pigments, vermilion, viridian, emerald green, cobalt green, cobalt blue, and bone black.

There are large white clumps scattered throughout the paint surface that may be related to the lead-white paint used. These mainly appear to originate from underlying layers or from within the upper paint layer (where white paint is mixed in with the tube colors), or possibly even from the ground layer, but are now exposed at the surface (fig. 12.83). Some of these white spots were retouched in a previous treatment (fig. 12.84).

Oil (estimated).

The painting has a spray coat of methacrylate L44/L46 and a spray coat of methacrylate L46, both applied in the 1960s. There appears to be an earlier layer of yellowed natural-resin varnish. The work has an even, somewhat glossy surface.

In an undocumented treatment, the painting was mounted onto hardboard. A canvas was then attached to the back of the hardboard and the painting was mounted onto a stretcher, which may be original to the work.

In 1960 the back of the canvas was vacuumed and the stretcher keys were fixed. Strip molding was applied. The painting was surface cleaned. Flaking paint along the edges was consolidated with wax-resin adhesive. Areas of abrasion were retouched. A spray coat of equal parts methacrylate L44 and L46 was applied.

In 1963 the painting was surface cleaned and a spray coat of methacrylate L46 was applied.

The painting is in good condition overall but has been impacted by alterations made by Manet and conservation treatment. The canvas was cut down by the artist on the top, bottom, and left sides; the composition extends onto these tacking margins. The current tacking margins are worn and deteriorated, with several losses in the fabric. In an undocumented treatment, the painting was mounted onto hardboard. A canvas was adhered to the back of the board and the painting was stretched on what appears to be the original stretcher. There are abrasions and losses in the paint and ground layers where the original composition extends onto the tacking edges and at the foldovers. There are several small paint losses along the top edge, mostly within the frame rebate area, and one just above the horizon on the right side. Retouching in these areas has been broadly applied, often without fills, and is discolored and mismatched, especially in the lighter areas of the sky; most of this is concealed by the frame. There is localized retouching along the other edges and other discolored retouching associated with white spots from the paint and/or ground layers that are exposed at the surface. There is fairly pronounced cracking throughout much of the surface, especially in areas that were more thickly built up. There are series of parallel cracks in places along the edges that appear to be the result of dried paint being folded over the edges when the new tacking edges were established. The painting is currently varnished with methacrylate resin, which imparts an even, somewhat glossy surface. There appears to be an earlier layer of yellowed natural-resin varnish.  
Kimberley Muir

Current frame (installed 1999): The frame is not original to the painting. It is a nineteenth-century French Second Empire Neoclassical scotia frame. The frame is water gilded over red-orange bole on gesso and composition and carved ornament with casein-painted sides. The gilding is burnished on the top fillets and cove sight with gilding left matte on the rest of the frame. The frame retains its original gilding and glue size. The pine molding is mitered and joined with angled dovetailed splines. The molding from the perimeter to the interior is fillet, scotia side, fillet, fillet, carved fluted flat dado, fillet, fillet, scotia, fillet, fillet, fillet with centered torus with beaded ornament, fillet, and fillet with cove sight (fig. 12.85). The frame’s section width is 15.2 cm (6 in.).

Previous frame (installed by 1933; removed by 1999): The painting was previously housed in a late nineteenth- to early twentieth-century Louis XIV ogee frame with swept sides and foliate rocaille cartouches, a hollow frieze, and an egg-and-dart sight molding. The frame had an independent fillet and cove liner (fig. 12.86, fig. 12.87).
